G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the **Brockton Division of the District Court Department** because the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Brockton, Massachusetts, and the Defendant conducts business in this venue. *See* G.L. c. 223, § 2; *Toland v. Paine Furniture Co.*, 281 Mass. 144 (1932).

*Toland v. Paine Furniture Co.*, 281 Mas.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the **Brockton Division of the District Court Department** because the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Brockton, Massachusetts, and the Defendant conducts business in this venue. *See* G.L. c. 223, § 2; *Toland v. Paine Furniture Co.*, 281 Mass. 144 (1932).
*Toland v. Paine Furniture Co.*, 281 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion in Toland v. Paine Furniture Co. deals with the sufficiency of service of process on a corporate trustee under G.L. c. 246 and c. 223, § 37, and with the resulting lien and bankruptcy issues. It does not discuss venue, the propriety of bringing actions in the Brockton Division of the District Court Department, or the effect of a defendant doing business in a particular locale. Citing Toland for the proposition about proper jurisdiction and venue in Brockton misstates the scope of the decision.
*Toland v. Paine Furniture Co.*, 281 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The governing statutes as to service of a writ upon one named therein as trustee are G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 246, § 5: ‘Trustee writs shall be served by copy on each trustee ...’ and in other respects as provided in G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 223, § 37. The latter section provides: ‘… In an action against a domestic corporation … service shall be made upon the president, treasurer, clerk, cashier, secretary, agent or other officer in charge of its business….’”

*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a duty of reasonable care arises where one undertakes to supervise minors. *See* *Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353 (2001); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353 (.support_reasoning: The Sullivan v. Brookline opinion is about reinstatement of a disability retiree and the interaction of G.L. c. 32, § 8(2) and G.L. c. 31, § 39. It does not involve supervision of minors, tort duties, or any discussion of a duty of reasonable care arising from undertaking to supervise minors. The case is purely about public employee retirement, retraining, and statutory interpretation, so it does not support the cited negligence proposition.
*Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353 (.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff, a twenty-year retiree of the Brookline police department (department), raises two issues through his petition for reinstatement: first, what standard should apply in evaluating a retiree’s fitness to return to full employment; and second, whether a long-term retiree must complete retraining before becoming entitled to reinstatement. To answer these questions this court must interpret G. L. c. 32, § 8 (2), and G. L. c. 31, § 39.

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a duty of reasonable care arises where one undertakes to supervise minors. *See* *Sullivan v. Brookline*, 435 Mass. 353 (2001); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.support_reasoning: The opinion in Glidden v. Maglio does not discuss, analyze, or decide any issue about a duty arising from the undertaking to supervise minors. The case concerns an adult property owner’s potential liability for injuries to adult workers (independent contractors) on scaffolding, focusing on causation and control over the work. The court explicitly declines to decide whether the defendant owed any duty of care at all, resolving the case solely on lack of proof of causation; there is no mention of minors or supervision doctrines.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.relevant_excerpt: “The motion judge found that the plaintiffs had not shown the requisite control necessary to impose a duty on the defendant. Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment. See St. Germaine v. Pendergast, 411 Mass. 615, 622-623 (1992) …”

*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.proposition: Defendant owed a legal duty to Plaintiff’s son to exercise reasonable care in the supervision of participants in its after-school program. *See* *Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401 (1991).
*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.support_reasoning: The case does not involve an after-school program or a custodial/supervisory relationship over a child participant. It concerns social host liability for an intoxicated guest at a private party and explicitly holds that the host owed no common-law duty to protect third parties on the highway where he did not serve or provide alcohol. Thus, it does not establish or affirm a duty of reasonable care in supervising participants in an after-school program and is being cited for a proposition it does not address.
*Ulwick v. DeChristopher*, 411 Mass. 401.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff claims that these circumstances impose a common law duty in negligence on the defendant for the protection of travelers on the highways…. Here, the defendant did not serve or make any alcohol available to Salvatore. The McGuiggan decision, therefore, does not afford a basis for the imposition of a common law duty on this defendant.… In the absence of such control in this case, we are not prepared to say that the common law should provide a remedy on the negligent encouragement theory advanced by the plaintiff.”

*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.raw_text: *Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.*, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901 (1987)
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to provide sufficient staff, neglecting to monitor children’s activities, and ignoring reports of rough play. *See* *Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.*, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901 (1987).
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a restaurant’s duty to protect patrons from injuries caused by an out-of-control vehicle crashing into the premises, focusing on foreseeability of that risk. It does not discuss staffing levels, supervision or monitoring of children, or responses to reports of rough play. The holding is that the incident was not reasonably foreseeable and thus no duty existed, which is unrelated to the proposition about breach via inadequate supervision of children.
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner or proprietor is not an insurer of the safety of his patrons. ‘The test is “foreseeable harm.”… The underlying duty in every case, however, is to exercise the care which the circumstances reasonably require.’ … The undisputed facts of this case make the injuries suffered by the plaintiffs the result of an incident which was not reasonably foreseeable by the defendant and thus not an occurrence from which it had a duty to protect its patrons.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions created an unreasonable risk of physical harm, particularly given its knowledge that unsupervised play among children can lead to serious injury. *See* *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006); *Carrier v. Riddell, Inc.*, 721 F.2d 867 (1st Cir. 1983).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition speaks of a defendant’s acts and omissions creating an unreasonable risk of physical harm based on knowledge that *unsupervised play among children* can lead to serious injury. Jupin v. Kask concerns negligent storage of firearms in a home with unsupervised access by a mentally unstable adult, focusing on foreseeability of criminal misuse of guns, not children’s unsupervised play or child-related injury risks. While it discusses unreasonable risk and foreseeability generally, it does not specifically or analogously address the children/unsupervised play context described in the proposition.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ … A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. … [A] defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.”

*Carrier v. Riddell, Inc.*, 721 F.2d 867.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions created an unreasonable risk of physical harm, particularly given its knowledge that unsupervised play among children can lead to serious injury. *See* *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141 (2006); *Carrier v. Riddell, Inc.*, 721 F.2d 867 (1st Cir. 1983).
*Carrier v. Riddell, Inc.*, 721 F.2d 867.support_reasoning: Carrier v. Riddell does not hold that defendant’s acts or omissions created an unreasonable risk of physical harm; instead, it assumes negligence arguendo and then holds there is no duty owed to the plaintiff because he did not use the defendant’s product. The opinion is focused on the absence of a legal duty in omission/failure-to-warn cases, not on expanding liability based on knowledge of risks from children’s unsupervised play or similar circumstances. It therefore does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
*Carrier v. Riddell, Inc.*, 721 F.2d 867.relevant_excerpt: "This basic, simplified account of general principle suggests that Riddell owes no duty to Carrier. Carrier is complaining about an omission, a failure to warn. Carrier does not allege any special actions or special relationships that might reasonably have led him to rely especially upon Riddell. In the absence of some special circumstance one would expect a purchaser or a user of a product to rely for warnings upon the maker of the product they buy or use, not upon the maker of another, similar product."

*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: The breach of duty was the proximate and foreseeable cause of the injuries sustained by Plaintiff’s son. *See* *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101 (1978).
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses proximate cause and foreseeability, holding that the authority’s negligent failure to secure the forklift could be found by a jury to have foreseeably resulted in the plaintiff’s injuries. The court explains that the intoxicated seaman’s conduct did not break the causal chain because such misuse was reasonably foreseeable, and concludes that a jury could find the injury was caused by the defendant’s negligence. This directly supports the proposition that the breach of duty was the proximate and foreseeable cause of the injuries.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable. … It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen who the authority knew had unfettered access to the cargo area. … Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, Defendant is liable for its negligent acts and omissions that caused injury to Plaintiff’s son.

*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.raw_text: *Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 438 Mass. 317 (2002)
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.proposition: The doctrine of *respondeat superior* renders Defendant vicariously liable for the negligence of its employees acting within the scope of their employment. *See* *Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 438 Mass. 317 (2002).
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that traditional respondeat superior applies to a corporate employer of a physician and that, once an employment relationship is established, the employer may be vicariously liable for the physician’s negligence committed within the scope of employment. The court rejects any special control requirement for medical employers and restates the general rule that an employer is liable for torts of employees acting in the scope of their employment, which matches the proposition cited.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.relevant_excerpt: “Broadly speaking, respondeat superior is the proposition that an employer, or master, should be held vicariously liable for the torts of its employee, or servant, committed within the scope of employment. … To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA. … ‘An employer is liable for torts committed by employees while acting in the scope of their employment.’”

*Popponesset Beach Ass\u2019n v. Marchil.raw_text: *Popponesset Beach Ass’n v. Marchillo*, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 586 (1996)
*Popponesset Beach Ass\u2019n v. Marchil.proposition: Defendant’s negligent supervision constitutes a breach of its obligation under Massachusetts common law and foreseeably caused Plaintiff’s son’s injuries. *See* *Popponesset Beach Ass’n v. Marchillo*, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 586 (1996); *Canni v. St. Paul Pioneer Press*, 169 F. Supp. 2d 205 (D. Mass. 2001).
*Popponesset Beach Ass\u2019n v. Marchil.support_reasoning: This opinion has nothing to do with negligent supervision, personal injuries, or a defendant’s duty to supervise; it concerns whether a beach association can compel lot owners to pay dues under various property and contract theories. The court’s analysis is about land registration, covenants, common schemes, implied-in-fact contracts, and unjust enrichment, not tort liability or foreseeability of injury. Citing this case for the proposition that negligent supervision breached a common-law duty and caused a child’s injuries misstates its holding and subject matter.
*Popponesset Beach Ass\u2019n v. Marchil.relevant_excerpt: An implied-in-fact contract comes into being when, notwithstanding the absence of a written agreement or verbal agreement expressing mutual obligations, the conduct or relations of the parties imply the existence of a contract... Providing an amenity or service that benefits the land of another, in the absence of invitation therefor, does not compel the owner of the benefited land to pay for it. LaChance v. Rigoli, 325 Mass. 425, 427 (1950).

*Canni v. St. Paul Pioneer Press*, 169 F.raw_text: *Canni v. St. Paul Pioneer Press*, 169 F. Supp. 2d 205 (D. Mass. 2001)
*Canni v. St. Paul Pioneer Press*, 169 F.proposition: Defendant’s negligent supervision constitutes a breach of its obligation under Massachusetts common law and foreseeably caused Plaintiff’s son’s injuries. *See* *Popponesset Beach Ass’n v. Marchillo*, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 586 (1996); *Canni v. St. Paul Pioneer Press*, 169 F. Supp. 2d 205 (D. Mass. 2001).
*Canni v. St. Paul Pioneer Press*, 169 F.case_name: Craig v. Bank of New York
*Canni v. St. Paul Pioneer Press*, 169 F.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns Massachusetts common-law negligent supervision and causation of a child’s injuries. This opinion is a federal diversity case governed by New York law about a bank’s duties under a trust agreement and statute of limitations; it does not discuss Massachusetts tort law, negligent supervision, or injuries to a plaintiff’s son. It therefore cannot be authority for the stated Massachusetts negligent supervision proposition and appears to be miscited in that context.
*Canni v. St. Paul Pioneer Press*, 169 F.relevant_excerpt: “Because BNY agreed to administer the trust from its offices in New York the Agreement is governed by New York law. … Plaintiffs allege that BNY breached both its fiduciary duties as trustee and the provisions of the Agreement entered into with Alpine. … A claim alleging a breach of an express trust agreement is subject to a six year statute of limitations.”
